posts.name: Benjamin Kravets
posts.cooked:
This year, my team has started tracking our battery usage (for FTC & FRC) to prevent overusing batteries and to evenly spread the usage between the batteries we have. We have been using a tracker that I made in Excel to do this.

My questions are:

Is it even worth it to do this - is battery degradation that much of a problem?

Is Excel the right way to do it? There has been some debate in my team about the best way to do it (mainly between Excel and just a paper sheet)

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
The biggest three pieces of advice you will probably get on here are not data monitoring system related for FRC, but generally just battery related

take care of your “comp” batteries (full charge cycles, don’t over use, no extensive practice, etc)

get rid of anything with high internal Impedance (may be down to wires (see team 95’s grasshopper nuts can be ordered here ), .02ohms measured is about the cutoff)

anything over 2 years old is probably in practice battery territory

All of the above can be done with a battery beak and a sharpie to mark the year it was put into rotation. How you do this is really up to you and what proves to be easy.

Do the couple large maintenance items above and don’t worry about the um-teenth very marginal gain by plotting stuff. It doesn’t matter unless you are a 99.9th percentile team or genuinely curious. Just keep an eye on battery heath and cycle stuff out.

Note: battery models new from the manufacturers are not created equal.

link_counts.title: QTY 2 - Grasshopper Nut for Battery Terminals

posts.name: Kiera Reed
posts.cooked:
Yes. It also helps to make sure you don’t accidentally forget to switch batteries, etc.

The best system is the one that works for your team. Excel has good data tools, paper might be easier at comps. I don’t think one is clearly better.

Some teams have made advanced battery trackers, like 6328’s scanner-based system:

FRC 6328 Mechanical Advantage 2022 Build Thread Open Alliance

Yes, especially over a longer competition. Its also useful so that you don’t reuse the same battery multiple times over, as that will degrade a battery significantly. Case in point some of our batteries from 2020 were only holding around 50% charge and would die immediately, meanwhile another of our 2020 batteries was literally unused.

Thats mostly up to how your team operates, but we have found just organizing a loop of batteries is a decent way to go, and we track which battery we used each match to ensure we fulfill the loop, or adjust accordingly should we need one of our better batteries for a crucial match.

posts.name: Eeshwar Krishnan
posts.cooked:
+1 for the battery beak and marking year of entry.

For FTC, we would start moving it to the “bad” category when they start reading more then 0.25-0.3 ohms of internal resistance. Also, when we got new batteries, we run a 2 minute practice session and note the battery voltage afterwards, and when practicing will keep an eye on batteries after practice runs or matches. Its not as critical as FRC where an aging battery will kill you in a match, its just an added bonus if you don’t have super high internal resistance.

I never had an excel sheet to track usage for FTC because we would just cycle them out as they emptied. We also had separate batteries for testing vs practice/competition so we didn’t wear the comp batteries too much just doing basic mechanism testing. I know some teams would just buy enough batteries to have one per match during events, and mark ahead of time which ones they would use for which match, but we just cycled out 5 batteries and numbered them to keep track.

I can double check, but I believe we tended to cycle out batteries every 2-3 years in FTC. If your bot isn’t super high power consumption they can easily last you a while.

posts.name: Nathan Villavicencio
posts.cooked: In addition to batteries to power the robot, my team has begun marking when the batteries on the drive hub were installed this is to prevent the problems that we were having with our drive hub. Currently, our drive hub turns off with the slightest touch and we thought it could be the battery, so we bought new ones. However, this did not fix the problem so we took the batteries out and marked when the battery was put in just so we could track the batteries. Also, consider getting us a new drive hub, Benjamin Kravets.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Not sure why this was flagged for moderation, just talking about FTC hub power from the preview of the post I saw …

posts.name: Nathan Villavicencio
posts.cooked: Yeah, I wasn’t sure either. Perhaps it was because I mentioned AZ Wolverine’s real name.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Well a lot of our profiles have our name in them if you click on them…

At any rate, don’t feel too bad about the post getting flagged, could have been a misclick.

posts.name: Nathan Villavicencio
posts.cooked: I don’t feel bad since he is on my team so I just asked him in person already.

posts.name: Eeshwar Krishnan
posts.cooked: Have you tried shimming the battery? Look under “unexpected shut down”

posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked: The post was flagged because it was from a new user replying to a post from the same IP. The system thinks it could be spam. It’s been cleared.

posts.name: Nathan Villavicencio
posts.cooked: Oh wow, that might just fix it. I’m so dumb. Thanks a ton!
